awd_titl_txt: Targeted Infusion Project: Implementation of an Integrative B.S. degree Program in Biochemistry within the Department of Chemistry
awd_abstract_narration: The goal of this Targeted Infusion project is to implement an integrative B.S. degree program in Biochemistry within the Department of Chemistry. The curriculum for this program was approved by the University Faculty in the spring of 2009. The decision to offer a B.S. in Biochemistry was made following several years of feedback from our chemistry graduates that pointed to the need for an undergraduate curriculum that allows more exposure and experience in biology. As is the case with many Chemistry programs, the Chemistry program at Hampton is designed along the traditional single discipline mentality, allowing for very limited opportunity for interdisciplinary cross-fertilization. Only two entry level biology courses (introduction to Biology I&II) are required for our chemistry majors. Program integration is becoming increasingly necessary in the preparation of future scientists. With the implementation of this program, the Department of Chemistry will offer two baccalaureate degrees: the traditional B.S. degree in Chemistry, and a B.S. degree in Biochemistry. Both degree programs meet the American Chemical Society certification requirements.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report 

Project Title: “Targeted Infusion Project: Implementation of an Integrative B.S. degree Program in Biochemistry within the Department of Chemistry”

PI: Isai T. Urasa

Awardee: Hampton University

Award Number: 1036306

Program Officer Name: Claudia Rankins  

Background

The Department of Chemistry at Hampton University is committed to providing an environment and educational experiences that allow students to acquire knowledge, skills, and abilities for future careers in research, education, industry, and health-related professions. Over 80% of our chemistry graduates pursue postgraduate training at renowned research institutions, including Johns Hopkins, Duke, U.N.C. Chapel Hill, Harvard, University of Maryland, University of Pennsylvania, Temple University, and many others. The B.S. degree program in Biochemistry was established in 2009 in response to persistent feedback from our alumni, pointing to the need for an undergraduate curriculum that allows more integration of chemistry and biological sciences. The alumni suggestions were consistent with our own needs assessment studies with respect to the training of future chemical/biomedical research scientists.

Objectives/Intellectual Merit

The objective of the project was to implement a baccalaureate degree program leading to a B.S. in Biochemistry, within the Department of Chemistry. The program was carefully designed to incorporate key concepts of biological, chemical, and other sciences to provide the student an integrated educational experience. Program integration is achieved through cross-disciplinary topics and methodologies in classroom and laboratory activities; Team Teaching; and Guest Lecturing. The curriculum provides a structure that allows students to see, experience, and learn about the makeup and functions of cellular components (proteins, carbohydrates, lipids, nucleic acids, and other biomolecules). It also reflects on how biology combines with organic chemistry, inorganic chemistry, physical chemistry, and mathematical concepts to elucidate the mechanisms by which living things obtain energy from food; the chemical basis of heredity; and biological changes related to disease. The laboratory component encompasses state-of-the-art equipment and materials to support a modern biochemistry curriculum.

Outcome

The establishment of the Biochemistry program did not only respond to the curriculum improvement suggestions mentioned  above, but it was also meant to provide an expanded field of career options for chemistry and other science students. As in all science and engineering (STEM) fields, minorities are acutely underrepresented in Biochemistry and the biomedical research workforce as a whole. It was expected that this program would be especially appealing to those students who may have had medical career aspirations but might be influenced to pursue future careers in a STEM area. Indeed, many of the students in the program fall in this category. Currently, the program has an enrollment of 21 students. Twelve students have completed the curriculum since its inception in 2009. Most of the graduates are pursuing advanced degrees in graduate school and/or medical school.   The long-term goal is to increase the total chemistry student enrollment from 70 to 100±5 students, with 25-30% of those pursuing the biochemistry curriculum.   

With the implementation of this program, the Department of Chemistry now offers two baccalaureate degrees: a B.S. degree in Traditional Chemistry and a B.S. degr...
por.por_txt_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report 

Project Title: "Targeted Infusion Project: Implementation of an Integrative B.S. degree Program in Biochemistry within the Department of Chemistry"

PI: Isai T. Urasa

Awardee: Hampton University

Award Number: 1036306

Program Officer Name: Claudia Rankins  

Background

The Department of Chemistry at Hampton University is committed to providing an environment and educational experiences that allow students to acquire knowledge, skills, and abilities for future careers in research, education, industry, and health-related professions. Over 80% of our chemistry graduates pursue postgraduate training at renowned research institutions, including Johns Hopkins, Duke, U.N.C. Chapel Hill, Harvard, University of Maryland, University of Pennsylvania, Temple University, and many others. The B.S. degree program in Biochemistry was established in 2009 in response to persistent feedback from our alumni, pointing to the need for an undergraduate curriculum that allows more integration of chemistry and biological sciences. The alumni suggestions were consistent with our own needs assessment studies with respect to the training of future chemical/biomedical research scientists.

Objectives/Intellectual Merit 

The objective of the project was to implement a baccalaureate degree program leading to a B.S. in Biochemistry, within the Department of Chemistry. The program was carefully designed to incorporate key concepts of biological, chemical, and other sciences to provide the student an integrated educational experience. Program integration is achieved through cross-disciplinary topics and methodologies in classroom and laboratory activities; Team Teaching; and Guest Lecturing. The curriculum provides a structure that allows students to see, experience, and learn about the makeup and functions of cellular components (proteins, carbohydrates, lipids, nucleic acids, and other biomolecules). It also reflects on how biology combines with organic chemistry, inorganic chemistry, physical chemistry, and mathematical concepts to elucidate the mechanisms by which living things obtain energy from food; the chemical basis of heredity; and biological changes related to disease. The laboratory component encompasses state-of-the-art equipment and materials to support a modern biochemistry curriculum.

Outcome 

The establishment of the Biochemistry program did not only respond to the curriculum improvement suggestions mentioned  above, but it was also meant to provide an expanded field of career options for chemistry and other science students. As in all science and engineering (STEM) fields, minorities are acutely underrepresented in Biochemistry and the biomedical research workforce as a whole. It was expected that this program would be especially appealing to those students who may have had medical career aspirations but might be influenced to pursue future careers in a STEM area. Indeed, many of the students in the program fall in this category. Currently, the program has an enrollment of 21 students. Twelve students have completed the curriculum since its inception in 2009. Most of the graduates are pursuing advanced degrees in graduate school and/or medical school.   The long-term goal is to increase the total chemistry student enrollment from 70 to 100±5 students, with 25-30% of those pursuing the biochemistry curriculum.   

With the implementation of this program, the Department of Chemistry now offers two baccalaureate degrees: a B.S. degree in Traditional Chemistry and a B.S. degree in Biochemistry. Both degrees are certified by the American Chemical Society. The name of the department was changed to "The Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry" to highlight the identities of the two degree offerings.

Impact

This program places Hampton University in a rather unique position in three respects: (1) we are among very few institutions that offer an undergraduate degree in Biochemistry; only three other HBCUs offer...
